website_summaries.verdict: One of a few external audio interface options for high quality music and sound recording on the go.
pros: Comes with dual recording inputs for true stereo recording capabilities
Audio interface includes separate software settings for accurate recording
cons: Some laptops require new or updated drivers to get the full functionality of the audio interface

customer_reviews.title: Fail —> iMac 18,3 for SPD/IF Surround Encoded Output
customer_reviews.text: The Apple iMac 18,3 is one of the first Apple computers in memory to eliminate SPD/IF capacity from its 3.5mm audio jack. Looking for a way to get ac3/ Dolby Digital 5.1 out of iTunes and/ or the DVD player app (VLC, etc.), I was hoping this USB adaptor would help. It didn’t. [iMac 5k (18,3), MacOS 10.14.4 Mojave, 1tb SSD, 32gb RAM — DVD Player.app, iTunes.app, VLC.app, etc. for ac3/ Dolby Digital 5.1 encoded audio stream to Harman Kardon surround receiver/ decoder. MacPro 5,1 without this adaptor but everything else the same works flawlessly.]
customer_reviews.author: David Lee Kelting

customer_reviews.title: This product itself is great, but make the switch to digital.
customer_reviews.text: Absolute must-have for the Behringer mixing board if you do any recording from it. It works well, very well, but the fact of the matter is if you're recording on a shoestring budget like I am, and cannot afford 500 dollar mixing boards and 30,000 dollar vacuum tube amps, just make the switch to digital recording. I recommend the ZOOM h5 or h6 (depending on budget and needs) since they offer multitrack recording AND multitrack INTERFACING WITH COMPATIBLE DIGITAL AUDIO WORKSTATIONS! It works great for me, using a mac and Adobe Audition. You cut down on a huge amount of noise and get full control over your audio.
customer_reviews.author: Dav

customer_reviews.title: Sound crisp and clean.  Works great on Ubuntu 14.04.
customer_reviews.text: My laptop built-in audio hardware would buzz when the power cord was plugged in, but not this unit. I haven't had it long, but I'll update if there are any problems with it-- so far, it's awesome! The description mentions Mac and Windows, but not Ubuntu, so I thought I'd mention it here: 1) Plug the UCA202 into the computer 2) Click the speaker icon at the top of the screen. Choose "Sound Settings..." from the drop-down menu 3) Choose the output and input as desired on the Behringer UCA202 rather than the sound card in the computer 4) Play and Record away with your audio program of choice!
customer_reviews.author: Timothy Wilson

customer_reviews.title: Looks easy, should have worked, but didn't.
customer_reviews.text: I tried to salvage some of my old albums by recording them to MP3. Audacity recommended Behringer as the best to work with this app. Directions looked easy, and I did lots of research on the settings when I couldn't hear it. Bottom line, it records silence. I can barely hear the music with earphones plugged into Behringer, and the screen looks like it's recording (noise levels fluctuate), but I get nothing. I brought the albums, turntable, and Behringer with me, and hope to try again someday.
customer_reviews.author: Jan Taylor

customer_reviews.title: Nice sound. Could use an equalizer.
customer_reviews.text: This replaced my SoundBlaster SB1560. The latter became unstable and wouldn’t play the audio of certain streamed videos. It would also blast my ears on occasion as it would lose control of the volume when using headphones. The Behringer was bought on the recommendation of a friend. He uses it when entertaining away from home. I love it at home! It has been rock-solid since the day I first installed it. I only gave it 4 stars because of one serious drawback. It does not come with an equalizer. I had to download the Peace Equalizer (you can find it on SourceForge). Together, they produce great sound! Dollar for dollar, I would rate this a ‘best buy’!
customer_reviews.author: William Thompson

customer_reviews.title: It's Been about a Year of Use and The Quality Still Persists!
customer_reviews.text: My gosh it's good to know that it managed to withstand an entire year with me and my recordings. It has been a true blessing and money saver. The quality is basically studio quality but it just can't get up to 24-bit quality of recordings or listening, but come on. You can totally still have sick sounds and amazing sound quality for these things. If you're trying to start off with a cheap recording set up, buy this. And THEN once you have enough confidence to spend more on equipment, go for a more expensive DAC. But 16-Bit quality is still legit ladies and gentlemen, and this is coming from a person of quality.
customer_reviews.author: TNBT

customer_reviews.title: Great little interface!
customer_reviews.text: I use this to get in-game sound through a mixer for streaming and also some studio recording use and I love it. No latency. No noise. Love the options, but mostly just use the RCA in / out with XLR -> RCA cables, though the optical port could be handy for lots of things. I use the headphones from the headphone amp on the mixer so I can’t speak to that, but again, it just increases configuration possibilities. Going to get a couple more of these because they make everything about interfacing with any kind of computer simple. No drivers, just works (tested on Mac and Windows 10)
customer_reviews.author: Tim Post

customer_reviews.title: This is the solution you need to have an optical connection for your MacBook / Mac Mini
customer_reviews.text: So even through Apple decided to eliminate the optical connections on there desktops / laptops, does not mean you want to. I was replacing a 2011 Mac Mini with a 2018 MacBook, and was trying to figure out how to connect back to my amplifier with TOS connection. Found this on Amazon and ordered it. The MacBook recognized it immediately and it work perfectly.
customer_reviews.author: Oskar Contreras

customer_reviews.title: Open Channel Z
customer_reviews.text: I dunno what I did wrong. Both right and left channels look identical, and when I listen to the original stereo source and subsequently monitor the output from this device, I don't hear all the information I knew to be there on the original. I've scoured the instructions, the net, trying to figure out what I'm doing wrong, but this device doesn't seem to work for me. Bummer. I still have 750 vinyls to transcribe...
customer_reviews.author: roboscratchTop Contributor: Camping

customer_reviews.title: I needed a solution for digital audio to my A.V. receiver. This worked well with MacBook Pro.
customer_reviews.text: I needed an external way to convert usb to optical so I could hook up my laptop to an A.V. receiver and get digital signal. This works exactly as I needed it to. I am using it on a 2018 MacBook Pro with no issues. The MacBook recognizes the usb audio right away and gives the option in settings to select it as your output. No drivers needed. The only negative is the optical cable pulls out of the unit too easily. I have to push it back in anytime I move it, even slightly.
customer_reviews.author: Chad L. Wilken

customer_reviews.title: Awesome deal, works perfectly.
customer_reviews.text: I had an Maudio Audiophile 2496 connected to a pair of desktop reference speakers, but then I upgraded the computer motherboard and discovered PCI slots were now out of fashion, leaving me with no way to use my speakers without adding a bulky desktop mixer and a host of cable adapters to convert from the on board headphone jack. This unit gave me direct plug and play functionality to connect my speakers once more, without taking up tons of precious desktop space!
customer_reviews.author: Deadweasel

customer_reviews.title: everything i have recorded in the past year has been ...
customer_reviews.text: everything i have recorded in the past year has been done using the UCA202 and a $100 Mackie mixer. if you want to hear (i am an amateur, so don't expect greatness..or even goodness, maybe), search 'soundclick', then use their search block for 'bandname'. it's 'cogbern'. i had read a technical review of the specs and performance of the UCA202. this unit allowed me to use Ubuntu Studio/Audacity to record, whereas i had had issues with many of the overly complicated programs prior to this setup. update (8/25/17): Am now using a Mac Mini for the computer-no issues, Behringer recognized at startup with Audacity as DAW.
customer_reviews.author: cogbern

customer_reviews.title: Good audio interface for digital recording apps
customer_reviews.text: I was looking for a USB audio interface that works with most digital audio recording apps. The UCA202 seems to be well supported in all the apps I've tried it with (Ardour, Sony Acid, etc). Works literally out-of-the-box with Linux or Windows. Audio quality seems very good to me. The switched monitor output is convenient. Quality seems good as does the overall value considering the price.
customer_reviews.author: eok

customer_reviews.title: Wasted time for a cheap price
customer_reviews.text: The unit works but all it did was add a load of unnecessary constant noise when plugged in. I spent an hour today trying to adjust, unplug, google, etc... finally gave up and will be returning this tomorrow. I shouldn’t known this was going to happen because it’s a Behringer, some of the worst cheap audio products I’ve seen. You get what you pay for...
customer_reviews.author: Charlie White

customer_reviews.title: After updated driver, worked fine.
customer_reviews.text: Got this to get sound from a PA system in to a Win10 v1809 PC for rebroadcast. Would not really work at first, had to download the latest driver from Behringer website. After that worked fine. This unit does not have a control on the gain of the incoming line level signal. The volume control on this unit is for the headphone jack only. This unit works, but if you want level control of that incoming signal, look at the UM2 for a few dollars more.
customer_reviews.author: DKelly

customer_reviews.title: Wow!!! Musician new friend.
customer_reviews.text: For under $30, great product. I was able to compare it with my Apollo MK2 and let me tell you, sound almost exact at the same level. I was testing this product using mainstage 3 for live performance along with the Apollo ($900) and to the untrained ears, you wouldn’t notice a difference. For recording, ok, not as great but it’s $29 bucks. For live performance or just audio out, great product. Blew me away by the quality. I would recommend this product to any musician who’s goals are using virtual instruments or just using a laptop to playback audio. And check this out, RCA vs Balance at that.
customer_reviews.author: David Yang

customer_reviews.title: solid quality
customer_reviews.text: Works really well with a Raspberry Pi 3. One of the few stereo audio input devices I could find, but I couldn't have asked for anything better, especially given the price. I do find that having the Monitor switch on works best which I found odd; but the output is noticeably louder and with no artifacts, so I just leave it on. I have not used the output, just the line in RCA inputs.
customer_reviews.author: Patrick

customer_reviews.title: A must have if you have a very portable set up like the Pioneer DDJ WEGO-3
customer_reviews.text: It does exactly what I needed it to do. Using Audacity to record DJ mixes and this works perfectly with the laptop. I can also covert the audio from the USB port and send it through the digital toslink connection of the receiver and get full multi-channel stereo. I travel with it now so that I can use the DJ set up to connect to a speaker system via USB, analog or digital. A must have if you have a very portable set up like the Pioneer DDJ WEGO-3.
customer_reviews.author: Jerome G.

customer_reviews.title: They Sound Great! Much better than your laptop's built-in sound.
customer_reviews.text: I now have three of these, and I keep finding more uses for them. They make great sound cards for Raspberry Pi's. If you are looking for better sound from your laptop or if your internal sound card is broke, give this a try. Most laptops only have a mono microphone input. I have used the stereo inputs on this to record live bands. And having that headphone adapter on the side is just handy.
customer_reviews.author: M. Kives

customer_reviews.title: A fantastic device, which I use to connect my Behringer
customer_reviews.text: A fantastic device, which I use to connect my Behringer, Ultragraph Pro, FBQ3102 HD, into the USB port of my ASUS Laptop which I have installed True RTA's, Real Time Spectrum Analyzer. This software program turns my laptop into a full power Oscilloscope, Spectrum Analyzer, Signal Generator. The Spectrum Analyzer incorporates FFT Analysis capability and you can elect 1st octave to 24th octave options.
customer_reviews.author: Sobeeit

customer_reviews.title: Satisfied
customer_reviews.text: This is by no means a great product but it helped me get my start. I also bought cable to go with this and just used the basic software on my Mac. I did not have the best tools at my disposal but this interface made a lot of things simpler. There was no need to download any drivers or other software or things of that nature. Its great for helping record demos or even a first small budget EP. If you do want to make a lot of sound though, I would suggest probably investing in something a lot better than can help you get the exact quality you want and give you the tones you like as well
customer_reviews.author: Louis Diaz

customer_reviews.title: Works great with my Laptop!
customer_reviews.text: Wanted something I connect to my receiver from my laptop that was not the headphone jack on the notebook. This device has great sound quality and I also used it to take the line level output from my cassette deck and record using the Audacity software. No drivers needed so far using windows 10. I recommend this!
customer_reviews.author: SLC Reviews

customer_reviews.title: Worked amazing for several years
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this several years ago and it worked wonderfully for quite some time. Great sound quality, super useful. I've used it as a headphone preamp, bridge between my laptop and a sound system with only optical audio, high quality DAC to amp before speakers, chaining together multiple sets of speakers, etc. Plays well with Linux, Bitwig, Ableton. However, one of the output channels has acquired a noisy buzz and I had to stop using it. I've upgraded to a Scarlett 2i4 by Focusrite which has proven to be an excellent purchase but far less mobile. Would have been 5 stars if it continued working.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: The Behringer UCA202 was the right decision for me
customer_reviews.text: Fantastic and functional. The cost belies the awesomeness. I needed this for two reasons: to digitize cassettes and improve computer sound, so this is an awesome upgrade for a regular old computer. My non-audiophile description of things is that I have good speakers hooked up to my computer but never liked the output, so I added this and it boosted levels, volume, and clarity without (yet) having to go the more expensive USB DAC route. I'm 100% happy.
customer_reviews.author: JulieTop Contributor: Pets

customer_reviews.title: I'm starting to do some live-streaming and needed this for ...
customer_reviews.text: I'm starting to do some live-streaming and needed this for my mic set-up. It's almost a need to have if you have the Behringer mini soundboard! My computer recognized it right off the bat! OBS pairs very well with this! Thanks you. It does exactly what I wanted it to do! Word of Advise: Behringer RCA OUT to U-control RCA IN; U-Control RCA OUT to Behringer RCA IN.... I hoe that helps!
customer_reviews.author: Sleepysnails

customer_reviews.title: Not "ultra low-latency", at least under Windows
customer_reviews.text: I'm sure this interface would work for some users, but the advertised "ultra low-latency" is why I bought it, to use with virtual instrument software in a live performance situation. Unfortunately it was not to be. At least for this Windows 10 user, the output latency was unacceptably high. The Behringer "driver" is just ASIO4ALL, which, though it works well for some, did not allow me to get the latency under about 10ms without distortion on a recent Core i7 ultrabook. Maybe the input latency is "ultra-low" but if you are a Windows user that needs low latency output with a native ASIO driver, look elsewhere.
customer_reviews.author: Matthew Moore

customer_reviews.title: WSJT-X, JS8CALL Ham Radio Digital Modes
customer_reviews.text: I bought this after reading a recommendation for it for Ham Radio digital modes. I have been pleased with it in general, however RF does get into the circuit if there is RF getting onto the radio. NOT a fault of the product. The stereo input and output is useful and allows for dual channel decoding of different frequencies if your radio has a dual VFO like the Elecraft KX3. I wish it had: metal case, volume attenuation controls on the lines shorter cable I can fix those however. W0GPR
customer_reviews.author: BG

customer_reviews.title: I absolutely love this thing
customer_reviews.text: I absolutely love this thing! It's very durable for a producer like me. I've been using this to transfer music I've made from my Playstation onto my laptop. Also being able to transfer music from cassettes, vinyl, & in extremely good quality, makes this well worth the purchase. I really wish I would bought this years ago.
customer_reviews.author: M.P.

customer_reviews.title: Works great for transferring LPs to CDs or MP4
customer_reviews.text: If you have an audiophile-quality turntable and stereo amplifier (or stereo receiver) that has tape-recording outputs, use this to transfer the audio from the amplifier to a USB connection on your PC. I have a Technics SL-Q2 turntable connected to a Yamaha RX-395 receiver, with the Behringer device connected to the Tape Out jacks. I connect the attached USB cable to my Lenovo T420i laptop, and of course am using Audacity to record. The quality is perfect.
customer_reviews.author: heavenlyday

customer_reviews.title: High quality and works in Ubuntu Linux
customer_reviews.text: I like this thing. It works fine for me in an Ubuntu PC set up for music. I am using it as a digital output to a stereo receiver and did produce a noticable improvement over the cell phones and other stuff I tried. It might not be a good choice for certain headphones though because of the high impedance. Very high quality
customer_reviews.author: Shoe Hallucination

customer_reviews.title: Works with iPhone.
customer_reviews.text: This also works with the iPhone. Plugging in through the lightning to USB adaptor, I was able to record stereo music video in the camera app and voice recorder. As far as I can tell, USB audio input is the only way to record stereo with these apps. I used the adaptor that also has lightning passthrough so I could provide power.
customer_reviews.author: David Bangs

customer_reviews.title: Works, EZ-PZ
customer_reviews.text: This thing works perfectly for my application. (connecting DDJ-SX2 to a laptop for broadcasting) and I'm pretty sure that anyone could hook up, and use this thing with only basic computer knowledge. It's simple and quick to setup, doesn't require any external power supply either which is really nice too. Definitely worth the money IMO
customer_reviews.author: STARSHAK3R

customer_reviews.title: Wouldn't record in stereo
customer_reviews.text: I tried everything--followed the instructions implicitly. I use Audacity and currently record from a professional mixing console. It works just fine. However, when I tried to record from console, using Audacity, with the Behringer U-Conrol it would only record in mono. The headphone jack was just fine, stereo sound, but the recording was only in mono. I have returned the unit.
customer_reviews.author: Rick S. Foster

customer_reviews.title: Works great for cassette deck to MP3 file
customer_reviews.text: I can't figure out how to connect my cassette deck to the device to the computer. There is no tech support. I hope someone here can help. I was unable to post a question in the Q&A. I connected the red & white cables from the back of the cassette to the UCA202. Where does the headphone cable go? From the deck to the UCA202? I thought so, then I connected the USB from the UCA202 to my laptop. Opened Audacity and when I recorded, I could see the waves, but no sound plays back. Please advise with detail. Thanks a bunch.
customer_reviews.author: Nan Dee

customer_reviews.title: Solid, Quality Performance
customer_reviews.text: This unit has worked fine for me the few times I have used it. It produces good quality sound/transfer through its various connectors. Okay, this is not a really high-end interface but, for the price, you can do a lot producing very good results. There are many other reviews (particularly Pennywhistler) with more detailed information for those looking to use this nice product for more than just occasional use. Overall, this is a nice interface for the casual user like me and even the more sophisticated audiophile. For the price, this is a great addition to your audio/music reproduction needs.
customer_reviews.author: Richard L.

customer_reviews.title: Sounds nowhere near as good as a SoundBlaster sound card or a Dragonfly USB ...
customer_reviews.text: Sounds nowhere near as good as a SoundBlaster sound card or a Dragonfly USB DAC. But, definitely a step up from a laptop's built-in soundcard. I have since bought a Dragonfly used on eBay for $35 and I think that's a much better route to go. Have had it 2 years and it's still going strong. I think I left the Behringer in my old work desk. No tears shed though.
customer_reviews.author: Jake

customer_reviews.title: Out of the box, hooked it up, NOTHING!
customer_reviews.text: Hooked it up to my Stanton T.92 Turntable to have more input gain sent to Audacity. At first, all I got was an "error, check source". Rebooted Audacity and then got a very low volume signal which was with the volume dial all the way up. Either this unit is defective or this is not meant for this application. VERY disappointed!
customer_reviews.author: Shopping Denoncourt

customer_reviews.title: Worked the first time I tried, but since then...
customer_reviews.text: ... not so much. I’d been trying to offload some mini-disc audio files from a Sony MDR to my Macbook Pro (since Apple decided we no longer needed to have an easy way to import). I discovered this gizmo would allow me to do it, but after one successful attempt, I’ve not been able to get any signal out of it. I wonder if the switch or input plugs were faulty. I haven’t tried since I first received it and should try again. If successful, I’ll give you an update. Actually, had seen similar experiences from other posters but thought I’d give this a go.
customer_reviews.author: The Voice

customer_reviews.title: Awesome!!
customer_reviews.text: What are you talking about?! I don't use this to record stuff from Spotify or Pandora! ... but yes it does its job perfectly as intended. Literally plugged it into my MacBook Pro's USB3. Wired up my device to record from, Used Audacity as the software to record. Reminds me of the good ol days of tape deck recording from the radio! Completely flawless no cons for what I am using it for.
customer_reviews.author: JohnJohnPR3

customer_reviews.title: Now you can turn you home studio into a professional one.
customer_reviews.text: This audio interface is just what you need to make any mixer compatible with your USB in put on your laptop or PC. Most VO artist as well as podcasters want to step up their game but simply do not know the necessary equipment to use. This little piece is a missing piece that many never even know exists. Just 4 rca jacks is all you need and the rest is magic. Simple interface to turn the complicated into something that any one can use.
customer_reviews.author: Earl Hall

customer_reviews.title: Can only use one
customer_reviews.text: It seems okay by itself, but you can't effectively more than one Behringer USB device at a time (including this and a Xenyx board, for example). The trouble is, they're identified exactly the same way, so although two devices show up, there's no way to keep track of them. They need a serial number in the USB description or something.
customer_reviews.author: LeifOfWilsonCreek

customer_reviews.title: A JT65 and Fldigi usb audio interface.
customer_reviews.text: I bought it for use with JT65 and "FLDIGI" on amateur radio. It uses the TI 48 khz chipset that has Microsoft drivers and shows up as just another audio input/output device. It uses RCA pin jacks for audio connection. It seems to work better than the onboard laptop audio as more signals are decoded with the UCA202 than with the internal audio chipset. The optical output of the UCA202 is OK but there is no optical input. The ultimate review on the UCA202 is [...] and that link includes enough info to do a bit of hardware hacking, like add an optical input and upgrade the audio amplifier to perfection. A really good deal at a really good price.
customer_reviews.author: J. Redding

customer_reviews.title: this device will not connect a turntable with a external  phono pre amp to your laptop.
customer_reviews.text: this is a great external sound card for music coming out of you laptop , but not sound going in in. i bought it to hook my turntable with a external phono preamp to my laptop it did not work for that. i watched a couple of videos on you tube on connecting it to the laptop and realized it is for output not input . though you would think it would be for both. so i hooked it up for output and it sounds great hooked into my stereo from my laptop better than just the head phone out jack on the laptop.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: digitizing, because you can't drive and play vinyl
customer_reviews.text: Allows you to bypass the 44hz max that most sound cards have and record @48+. Some releases where never released on any other medium, so this allows the user to record it so they can use it on the go
customer_reviews.author: Raven

customer_reviews.title: Great introduction to a DAC
customer_reviews.text: This is not my first UCA202, and it won't be my last. I love how much nicer everything I have hooked up to these units have sounded. It has provided a significant improvement in simple $40 computer speakers I use at work (it seriously made them sound like a set costing easily twice the money), as well as an astonishing improvement in my true all tube amplification (no op amps) for my Sennheiser HD600s. If you are unsure about the benefits of a DAC, just drop $30 on this puppy... it will blow your mind, and likely set you into the mode of seeing what higher end DACs can do.
customer_reviews.author: sandt38

customer_reviews.title: An easy way to convert cassette tapes into digital files.
customer_reviews.text: My husband's recently deceased father left him some old cassette tapes that his father recorded in the last few weeks of his life. My husband wanted to convert them to digital files so he could easily listen to the tapes and share the recordings with the rest of the family. This worked perfectly to convert them. He's not very tech-savvy, so it took him a while to figure our how to use it. (That is, it took him a while to get frustrated enough to ask me to show him how to do it.)
customer_reviews.author: Jesse Johnson

customer_reviews.title: This does the job beautifully and also works very
customer_reviews.text: I needed a netbook compatible audio interface to manage occasional field recordings from receivers and monitors at remote locations. This does the job beautifully and also works very, very well on my office laptop. Just as nice, you can download record/play software such as Audacity (similar to Adobe Audition) from Behringer's site for FREE. Want a way to cheaply record your musical creativity??? Couple it with a small mixer and you got it!
customer_reviews.author: Boogaloo

customer_reviews.title: Brighter, cleaner and punchier than integrated PC audio
customer_reviews.text: I'm using this to bypass my computer's (Windows 7) inferior integrated sound card and connect a home studio audio mixer that lacks integrated USB. My audio is now punchier, cleaner and more pleasing through my near-field studio monitors than it was before. Setup was ... well, there really was none. I plugged it in and it worked. I did have to select which speakers I wanted to hear in Windows' volume mixer, but that seems fundamental. Well worth the $20 I paid for this box. I'm very pleased witht he purchase and will recommend it to others.
customer_reviews.author: Woodland Dan

customer_reviews.title: Linux compatible and supports ASIO.
customer_reviews.text: Needed an audio solution that would work w/ Mixbus running on Ubuntu. This was inexpensive but does all that is required of it. Audio quality is actually very good. Works w/ Jack and Mixbus on Ubuntu studio. I am using that machine as a SMPTE LTC slave which provides synchronized audio to a Windows machine.
customer_reviews.author: B. Parker

customer_reviews.title: An affordable USB interface
customer_reviews.text: We were having a problem getting audio from a laptop headphone jack to the sound system at our senior citizens' center. I bought this interface and have not had any problems since. It serves our purpose well.
customer_reviews.author: Lee Salter

customer_reviews.title: really good for the money
customer_reviews.text: had a high end audio analog card before that i could not use on my new pc. was reluctant to get something this cheap as i am an audiophile, but was pleasantly surprised. easy to use and set up
customer_reviews.author: David K. Phillips

customer_reviews.title: Works fine, needs gain control.
customer_reviews.text: It works OK, but wish it had a gain control. My application does not provide any means to control the signal strength, so it would have been nice to have an interface device with a gain control. After I discovered that, I looked some more and did not find one with a gain control. I guess the industry expects that to be built into the recording ap. Not true with Android recording aps, at least not any I could find.
customer_reviews.author: John E. Wente

customer_reviews.title: Love it! This setup is excellent and in my ...
customer_reviews.text: Used this along with a pair of Micca MB42X Bookshelf Speakers, Dayton Audio SUB-1000 10-Inch 100 Watt Powered Subwoofer and SMSL SA50 50Wx2 TDA7492 Class D Amplifier as a 2.1 setup for my computer. Love it! This setup is excellent and in my opinion so much more capable than most packaged PC sound systems. This DAC installed with no need for software on my Windows 10 machine and immediately began supplying the amp with clean audio. I'm very happy with my purchase and would make it again.
customer_reviews.author: J. Allen

customer_reviews.title: Windows 10 users
customer_reviews.text: It doesn’t work straight out of the box with current (9/2018) windows 10 and the current uca202 device driver. Contact Behringer tech support to get a link to an earlier driver that will work perfectly to create 2 channel 16-bit 14400Hz analog to digital. Note if you have high security on your system it may block leading changes to the registry
customer_reviews.author: Amazing Consumer

customer_reviews.title: Works Great With Linux
customer_reviews.text: The device was plug and play for me on a system running Devuan Ascii (Debian derivative without systemd) under KDE and using Audacity to capture audio in stereo. In short, no device drivers to load, the system just recognized it. NOTE: you do need to be able to figure out how to switch to using the device within Audacity. If you're all ready familiar with Audacity, you shouldn't have any problems.
customer_reviews.author: Señor Bob

customer_reviews.title: Pretty good
customer_reviews.text: It's very small, easy to hide, good quality RCA inputs, but the headphone output for monitoring and audio-out is pretty meh. Tends to be slightly inaccurate with my Koss Pro-4AA headphones, so I monitor with my mixer's output. Great link from analog out, to a digital input for your equipment. If you need a interface on the cheap that works, this'll do you well. I also feel that saving your money wouldn't be a bad idea, either, if you want have better monitoring.
customer_reviews.author: Spencey

customer_reviews.title: Nice device for recording
customer_reviews.text: The main reason I got this device for, is for recording audio on my laptop, which doesn't have any Line-in port. I am using it on Ubuntu 18.04, it has plug and play support in it, I didn't have to install any additional driver or anything. I love it for recording, it captures with very good quality, for playback I am not a fan, it has a very loud hiss in the background, so for audio output I will stick to my laptop's headphone out.
customer_reviews.author: gabriel

customer_reviews.title: Easy Kodi (xmbc) Addition with Raspberry Pi
customer_reviews.text: I recently purchased a Raspberry Pi 2. Running Kodi 14.2 (Helix), it's actually a forked version, Openelec. The Pi picked up the Behringer UCA202 right away. All I had to do was change the audio output in the system settings. As for sound improvment, that has yet to be determined because I've only been using these cheap bundled eMachine speakers. But I'm sure it is an improvement over the onboard sound. I'll find out soon when I hook this up to the surround sound. But for now, I at least know it's plug-n-play with the Pi2/Kodi setup.
customer_reviews.author: Rozerem

customer_reviews.title: Essential tool for the DJ livestreamer
customer_reviews.text: I used this product recently for a DJ livestream and it functioned perfectly. What I really like are the passthrough RCA ports that allowed me to daisy chain my monitors to the DJ deck. The device was effectively plug and play on my MacBook (Catalina) and OBS streaming software.
customer_reviews.author: D. NGUYEN

customer_reviews.title: Does the job
customer_reviews.text: It connected easily, installed the drivers with no problem, and was recognized by Audacity. It's hard to say how good the conversion is since I'm using it to convert old reels and cassettes filled with live concert recordings that often aren't the best quality to begin with. Still, I can't really hear any difference between the analog source and the output (24 bit/ 48 kHz). You can, of course, choose whatever sampling rate you want. I'm sure it isn't as good as a Lynx HiLo a/d converter, but it isn't $2500 either. I'm pretty sure it does a better job than my internal soundcard if just because the electronics are isolated from the computer electronics.
customer_reviews.author: D. KULICK

customer_reviews.title: Excellent
customer_reviews.text: Does what it's supposed to do. Connect your tape player with cables provided and connect to your computer with USB cable. Digital output is sent to your computer. You'll need software like Audacity (free) to save it to your computer's disk
customer_reviews.author: JB

customer_reviews.title: Worked as it should
customer_reviews.text: So USB interface worked good. The thing I would liked it to have is a connector on the unit for the USB cable so I could change the length of the cable to suit my needs.
customer_reviews.author: RifGuy

customer_reviews.title: The Behringer's analog RCA inputs sound fantastic streamed to my Sonos speakers
customer_reviews.text: I used this in my "Add Aux to Sonos Using Raspberry Pi" on Instructables. You'll have to Google it since I can't link it here. I wanted to add a remote line-in to my Sonos system without having to buy another Play 5 or CONNECT. The Behringer's analog RCA inputs sound fantastic streamed to my Sonos speakers.
customer_reviews.author: replayrebTop Contributor: Camping

customer_reviews.title: GREAT GREAT GREAT
customer_reviews.text: The folks at Amazon rejected my first review which read "perfect transaction" but it seems they want fairly wordy feedback, which I might have provided if this were a work worthy of critical review and there was anything to say other than "it works and I'm happy." In some ways, Amazon is brilliant, but when they are dumb, they are dumber than a bucket of ice. Rejecting feedback due to length is DUMB! I am happy with my purchase, PERIOD! And I love Amazon, mostly!
customer_reviews.author: Kenneth Allen

customer_reviews.title: Never let me down
customer_reviews.text: Great product. I have an old Behringer Eurorack MX 1804X mixing board. This allows me to run my mixer into the computer to edit audio. It also allows for the computer to run back into the board and then out to speakers. Just plug the usb into the computer, and hook the ins and outs up, and tada. Had it about a month. Never failed, works every time.
customer_reviews.author: LongTallDog

customer_reviews.title: Great audio interface.
customer_reviews.text: Works great. Perfect for monitoring audio while recording it. Compact in size and price. It's a great audio interface. It's perfect for people who wanna record live audio on their computer utilizing audio recording software but don't have an audio input jack.
customer_reviews.author: Ronald C. Miihlbach

customer_reviews.title: this is a cool device. For what I do
customer_reviews.text: I had to change the rating from 4 stars to 5, because I actually got around to setting up my DAW, and wow. very low latency. For the price, this is a cool device. For what I do, it is the right fit.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Too Noisy
customer_reviews.text: This was my 2nd one because it's a convenient way to run sound from my PC to my stereo receiver but there's a high pitched frequency that constantly bleeds with this thing and I definitely won't be buying another. At first, I thought it was just the original unit that went bad but the 2nd one is doing it too. Waste of money.
customer_reviews.author: VinC710Top Contributor: Photography

customer_reviews.title: Very Happy With It
customer_reviews.text: This is an excellent way to record my guitar riffs onto my computer as I've been trying to figure out how to record silently. So I just plug my guitar pedals straight to this device with a 1/4 to L/R RCA cable then plug the device's usb cable to my laptop. I've seen other great audio interfaces, however, they are all over-priced. But this does not break the bank.
customer_reviews.author: Swrvl

customer_reviews.title: Works ok for REW
customer_reviews.text: Automatically recognized by Windows x64, no drivers needed or available anyways. With Windows 64bit the line-input is missing but there is a Microphone input level you can adjust for the UCA202. What's weird is that if you install the ASIO drivers from Behringers website, that Microphone input is changed to Line-in. The biggest problem with the uca202 is the weird hump below 20hz when using a spl meter or mic. Here is a thread at avsforum explaining this [...] It does well for 20hz-20khz but if you have a mic thats calibrated from 5hz-20khz then I would look at something else like the Tascam US-144MKII.
customer_reviews.author: JimBob

customer_reviews.title: Great Sound Card
customer_reviews.text: Great Accessory Sound Card I bought this to trick my computer into recognizing two sound cards. I wanted to transfer records and tapes to my computer hard drive, without having the computer card interfere. This works great. If you want to use the internal sound card, this provides a separate headphone monitor source, without readjusting the recording volume. Very inexpensive, and quite small. If necesaary, a built-in preamp (for magnetic cartridge record transfer or mike pickup) would have been nice, but an outboard preamp will work fine. Line sources (VCR, cassette deck) are OK without any preamp. Finally, it is USB powered. No clunky power supply or wall wart required.
customer_reviews.author: Knot Me Mb Sc

customer_reviews.title: Must-buy for people who need ASIO drivers on a budget!
customer_reviews.text: I recently got into playing the EWI, and required low latency ASIO drivers. ASIO4ALL drivers worked, but would lock up the audio/video on everything except the one program using the driver. By plugging my headphones and studio monitors into this interface, and installing the drivers from the Behringer website, I could make whatever sound I wanted, the way I wanted, when I wanted!
customer_reviews.author: Cameron O'Neill

customer_reviews.title: Just plug it in (instead of wearing out your laptop's headphone jack)
customer_reviews.text: This a inexpensive and simple method of getting decent sound out of your laptop. Just plug it in, plug in some powered speakers and enjoy. Many other functions are built into this well built module but the above ability alone is worth it to me.
customer_reviews.author: Alan S. Mathias

customer_reviews.title: Verge of Returning Product
customer_reviews.text: I am on the verge of returning this because none of the promised software is available from Behringer, I even registered the device and got an email but the link given for the downloads is bad. I wrote the seller as provided by Amazon but so far no reply. It is okay but limited in usefulness.
customer_reviews.author: Clint

customer_reviews.title: Works very well
customer_reviews.text: With the free Audio program with this device works so well I've found new soundtracks for my home movies from old records. And while connected to my audio turner and laptop I can play my Amazon Music through the AV tuner.
customer_reviews.author: Michael T. Feeney

customer_reviews.title: Easy to use, and I'm quite pleased with its performance!
customer_reviews.text: Bought this to run with my laptop in order to boost the output with a higher signal-to-noise ratio. Traditional laptop sound cards don't offer high output, and as such need something to boost the signal. This is especially true if you're running a DJ setup, and your mixer or mixing board doesn't have a built in sound card or amplifier available. This allows me to run minimal equipment, and provide a decent output.
customer_reviews.author: Vincent

customer_reviews.title: Works on Android too!
customer_reviews.text: Works exactly as I wanted. I honestly would have paid more for this if I had too. It works flawlessly on my Android device (with a $4 adapter) using Audio-Evolution and it isn't even designed for that.
customer_reviews.author: Chuck H.

customer_reviews.title: Works great in conjunction with a small tape deck
customer_reviews.text: I've been using this in conjunction with a new old stock Realistic SCP-32 tape deck to transfer some old tapes to digital files. Quality is much better than the cheap audio chip on my old Lenovo workstation.
customer_reviews.author: Brian

customer_reviews.title: Does the job mostly, but you get what you pay for.
customer_reviews.text: My Firebox broke, so I needed something just to get sound out of my computer until I replace it. For less than $30 this is fine, but I'm only giving it 4 stars due to the low price- not sound quality. The sound is better than what you'd get from the headphone jack on your motherboard, but nothing to write home about.. It certainly isn't for anything other than watching TV, games or demo music recording, etc, but no one is claiming that it's a pro audio box. It's a cheap audio interface with a few nice features and passable audio for most people. Definitely worth the price as long as you keep in mind what you're getting.
customer_reviews.author: BTM

customer_reviews.title: Decent audio device for the price
customer_reviews.text: Pros: Affordable High quality audio (no consistent distortion) Cons: Sputtering and popping on all hosts: Mac OS 10.8, Windows 7 SP1, Windows 8.1 With default Core Audio or Windows drivers, Behringer drivers or ASIO4ALL on several different computers I experienced occasional clicking and popping coming from both headphones and phone outputs. It comes in random bursts and usually around the time sound is playing and afterward. I ended buying this Tascam USB audio interface  to replace the Behringer UCA202

customer_reviews.title: exactly what i needed for live dj radio broadcasts & recording of mixes
customer_reviews.text: exactly what i needed for live dj radio broadcasts & recording of mixes. headphone jack line in wasnt cutting it, this works great. i stream my dj show worldwide with this badboy!
customer_reviews.author: Nicholas C.

customer_reviews.title: It works great!
customer_reviews.text: Got this based on other reviews, especially one who took the time to really expound on it. I used it for recording a cassette to computer, but I really bought it to use to interface my mixing board with my computer. Should work just fine. The seller was fast, getting it to me over 2 weeks ahead of the projected arrival date. If you've used other Behringer equipment, you may or may not be impressed with their quality. Just remember, that although they may be engineered in Germany, they are made in China. Enuf said. This particular unit seems to be built pretty well, but time will tell.
customer_reviews.author: Techie

customer_reviews.title: A great deal!
customer_reviews.text: This unit works flawlessly on Mac OS 10.6.2 Snow Leopard in 64-bit mode and without the need to load any drivers. This unit is nothing fancy but at its price point, I can't see how anyone could expect it to be. It gets 2 channels in, 2 channels out, and has a headphone send. Pretty much everything you need for basic recording. The plastic of the enclosure seems like it could be sturdier but mine never moves, it just dangles behind the computer. It may be an issue for someone who takes it everywhere, though. It sounds good to. I made it the default sound output for the Macintosh and it sounds good for movies and music.
customer_reviews.author: CDM

customer_reviews.title: Very straightforward
customer_reviews.text: I use this for recording and monitoring on my MacBook, primarily with Logic and Traktor. My roommate has this same sound card and I used it a few times before deciding that the price point was low enough to get one for myself. It's low latency, plug-and-play (no issues whatsoever), assignable channels, sounds good enough to play in a studio or small venue, etc., etc.. I definitely recommend it as something for musicians or DJs to have in your bag along with an RCA-to-RCA cable.
customer_reviews.author: amzemm

customer_reviews.title: No input volume control
customer_reviews.text: It states that no software needed for this device to work properly; I even used a recommend software (Audacity) and I couldn’t make it to work; the input volume control does not work it’s too low
customer_reviews.author: tootoohotforyou

customer_reviews.title: Works Great
customer_reviews.text: The available RCA jacks for output and the headphone jack are excellent features in a product at this price point. As advertised, I hooked this up to my Win7 laptop, the one with the broken headphone jack, and ended up with a working external audio DAC for the laptop. Audio sounds good through the desktop speakers. The only issue I have is that the USB cable is too long and clutters up my desk a bit so I had to use the wire tie to tie it up a bit. I definitely wanted the DAC to sit off of a USB cable for strain relief and I've achieved that goal here. Success. Thanks.
customer_reviews.author: Arch Hughes

customer_reviews.title: Nice little DAC
customer_reviews.text: Behringer has a solid reputation, but they have moved toward the consumer lower end market as of late. This product works very well. Setup is dead simple as it is a plug and play device. Plugging the unit into my laptop enabled the DAC and diabled my embedded DAC immediately. Unplugging it restores previous laptop audio functions. I am using this with a pair of Grado headphones using iTunes recorded digital audio. Very clean and open sound. For $30 or less it is hard to beat.
customer_reviews.author: Noneya!

customer_reviews.title: Sounds great to me
customer_reviews.text: This DAC sounds way better than the SB FX sound card that it replaced. It's the perfect companion for any of the cheap mini-amps out there. If you want the cleanest sound possible from your PC/laptop, then you owe it to yourself to get this.
customer_reviews.author: Suntoryjim

customer_reviews.title: A real bargain
customer_reviews.text: I own three of these items, and after several years I'm still completely satisfied with all of them. The audio quality is surprisingly good, more than good enough for an entertainment system, and a vast improvement over the audio circuits found in most laptops. For a home studio I might consider something higher-end, but for non-professional use these are exactly the right thing, and inexpensive enough that I can afford to have one for each stereo system in the house. I usually avoid Behringer, because I've owned other (more expensive) Behringer products that failed on me, but about this product I have no complaint.
customer_reviews.author: chris korda

customer_reviews.title: A Great External Sound Card for your Laptop
customer_reviews.text: Yo folks, This is a LINE level device with RCA ins and outs. Am using it with my stereo system and computer ( laptop ) which has the typical, almost awful built in sound card. Download the USB driver from Behringer for better functionality. There is a version of this box that also has a RIAA magnetic phono cartridge preamp built into it. This is not an Audiophile device, but it has performance that is so much better than I expected. Clearly, others have had a similar experience.
customer_reviews.author: hifidoc

customer_reviews.title: Don't count on any software
customer_reviews.text: Unit may work...I don't know...haven't used it yet. But.....software sucks. Audacity won't load, mixer not even downloadable, other software won't work! No downloads for advertised mixer, etc. either....too bad
customer_reviews.author: Jack Aldridge

customer_reviews.title: Great little device to move my audio output away from ...
customer_reviews.text: Great little device to move my audio output away from my computer. Got this because there was a lot of noise in my speakers when running a 3.5mm cable to a Y splitter to RCA to my amp. Didn't want to drop the cash for a serious "audiophile" (whatever that means) DAC. This inexpensive little piece of hardware cleaned all that noise up at a pretty damn reasonable price. Would definitely recommend this as a DAC for use in a 2.0 speaker setup.
customer_reviews.author: Emily

customer_reviews.title: Works great, I'm happy
customer_reviews.text: Really happy with this. I was trying to play mp3's from my computer's earphone jack to the stereo and just wasn't getting the volume. Sounded like crap. Going through the USB it is much louder, sounds moderately (noticeably) better. I still don't have -great- quality sound, but my humble equipment is at its limits, lol
customer_reviews.author: Gordon Robbins

customer_reviews.title: Exactly what I wanted
customer_reviews.text: Received this little interface to put vinyl on my hard drive. Used "Audacity" (which is free) and plugged the usb into my laptop. Plugged a RCA jack into one of the outputs on my receiver that you would use to record to a tape player or cd recorder and the other end into the input jacks on the Behringer. Next,I put on an album and adjusted the input volume on Audacity. Then I played the album and recorded. That simple!! Sound quality is great. Used a de-clicker program a friend recommended and output wav files. This is all you need. A great little product.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Works perfectly; produces high-quality audio
customer_reviews.text: Works as advertised (and perfectly), which is a rarity in inexpensive audio adapters. Sometimes you just need to digitize audio from RCA connectors; I used this to digitize some old family cassette recordings.
customer_reviews.author: Bradford Needham

customer_reviews.title: Channels don't work individually. Frustrating for DJing
customer_reviews.text: I got this for effects DJing along with a NUMARK MIXTRACK. You can't use this to listen to your headphones and output audio as two separate channels. It doesn't require drivers but I found that some software (TRAKTOR) will need ASIO4ALL to allow you to use it. Virtual DJ was pretty frustrating also but mainly because of its unrelated instability issues. As far as quality goes, it sounds ok but I haven't had the chance to try it with any high quality monitor or PA system yet. Probably will return it and get a controller with built in audio, like the MIXTRACK PRO.
customer_reviews.author: AZ MTBer

customer_reviews.title: Nice Inexpensive USB Interface
customer_reviews.text: Never got a Behringer product I didn't like and this is no exception. Using it to convert the analog output from a really old Lineartech SL-950 six channel mixer into various laptops and desktops for audio recording. Works well on every platform OS from XP thru Win 8 -- mostly using Goldwave software and Behringer XM-8500 dynamic microphones to record interviews and voice tracks. Not tried this combo on MAC or Linux box yet but likely will one day.
customer_reviews.author: William M. Pasternak

customer_reviews.title: Great Little USB Preamp
customer_reviews.text: Behringer has another winner here. This company has a long history of offering low-priced gear that rivals the performance of the high-priced spreads, and this little USB line-level audio preamp is no exception. I have been very happy with the performance of the UCA202 with my REW software for system analysis and room equalization. Installation of the drivers available from the Behringer website was unnecessary with my Win 8.1 notebook. The MS drivers work fine.
customer_reviews.author: A. Sacremento

customer_reviews.title: WOW
customer_reviews.text: Added this to my home stereo setup and WOW. I originally ran a rca from my amp to my laptop but when I ran this between my laptop and amp it really cleaned the sound up. Took away the echo my speakers had. Definetly recommend adding this to any home stereo system.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: works with iphone XR & ios 12.1
customer_reviews.text: I was looking for an audio interface to use with my iphone to record music with line in. works 100% with the iphone camera connection cord. recommended.
customer_reviews.author: The Duke

product_meta.title: Behringer U-Control UCA202 Ultra-Low Latency 2 In/2 Out USB Audio Interface with Digital Output
product_meta.description:
Color:White

BEHRINGER U-CONTROL UCA202
Ultra-Low Latency 2 In/2 Out USB/Audio Interface with Digital Output

 * Ultra-flexible audio interface connects your instruments, mixer, etc. with your computer for recording and playback
 * High-resolution 48 kHz converters for high-end audio quality
 * Works with your PC or Mac computer - no setup or drivers required. Free audio recording and editing software downloadable at www.behringer.com
 * Stereo Headphone output with dedicated Level control lets you monitor both input and output
 * Additional S/PDIF optical output for direct digital conversion
 * Powered via USB - no external power supply needed
 * High-quality components and exceptionally rugged construction ensure long life
 * Conceived and designed by BEHRINGER Germany 

The UCA202 provides two analog mono inputs and outputs (for monitoring), USB connectivity and an additional S/PDIF optical output for direct analog-to-digital conversion. The stereo headphone output features a dedicated level control and lets you listen to both the input and output. 

IMAGINE THE POSSIBILITIES...
When used as a professional interface between a mixing console and your computer, myriad options become available. Some of these might include connecting the UCA202 RCA outputs: to the TAPE INPUT jacks of your mixer; to powered monitors or to the input channels on the mixer. Connecting to the mixer input channels allows you to use the Aux Send feature of your mixer to build an extremely versatile monitor mix for recording sessions. These are just a few of the possibilities; let us know how you use your UCA202. 

TONS OF FREE SOFTWARE
To truly get the most out of your UAC202, you will need recording and editing software. So, we decided to give you lots of free software to choose from. 

KRISTAL Audio Engine is a powerful multi-track recorder, audio sequencer and mixer - ideal for anyone getting started with recording, mixing and mastering digital audio. Kristal's main features include:

 * Mixing console
 * Audio sequencer
 * 16 audio tracks
 * 32-bit floating point audio engine
 * Sample rates from 44.1 to 192 kHz
 * 3-band parametric EQ
 * 2 VST insert slots per channel
 * 3 VST master effect slots
 * ASIO low-latency audio driver support

Audacity is an easy-to-use audio editor and recorder for Windows, Mac OS X, and Linux operating systems. With Audacity you can: 

 * Record live audio
 * Convert tapes and records into digital recordings or CDs
 * Edit Ogg Vorbis, MP3, WAV or AIFF sound files
 * Cut, copy, splice or mix sounds together
 * Change the speed or pitch of a recording
 * And much more...

VALUE
For a fraction of the cost of an over-priced USB audio interface from those other guys, you can have state-of-the-art digital conversion, world-class recording and editing software and hassle-free connectivity between your PC or Mac Computer and any piece of audio equipment. 

Bridging the gap between your music and the rest of the world - the BEHRINGER U-CONTROL UCA202.



AMAZON.COM
The UCA202 provides two analog mono inputs and outputs (for monitoring), USB connectivity and an additional S/PDIF optical output for direct analog-to-digital conversion. The stereo headphone output features a dedicated level control and lets you listen to both the input and output. For a fraction of the cost of many USB audio interfaces, you can have state-of-the-art digital conversion, world-class recording and editing software, and hassle-free connectivity between your PC or Mac Computer and any piece of audio equipment.

Hassle-free connectivity between your PC or Mac Computer and any piece of audio equipment. Click to enlarge. 

energyXT2 makes it easy to manipulate your audio and MIDI file. 

Audacity is an easy-to-use audio editor and recorder for Windows, Mac OS X, and Linux operating systems. 

Options Galore
When used as a professional interface between a mixing console and your computer, myriad options become available. Some of these might include connecting the UCA202 RCA outputs: to the TAPE INPUT jacks of your mixer; to powered monitors or to the input channels on the mixer. Connecting to the mixer input channels allows you to use the Aux Send feature of your mixer to build an extremely versatile monitor mix for recording sessions. These are just a few of the possibilities; let us know how you use your UCA202. 

No Drivers Required
The UCA202 works with your PC or Mac computer without the need for any setup or driver installation. 

Powered via USB
Because the UCA202 is powered by the USB bus, no external power supply is needed. That's one more outlet for all your musical toys. 

High-End Audio Quality
The UCA202 features high-resolution 48 kHz converters for high-end audio quality, and the additional S/PDIF optical output allows for direct digital conversion. 

Tons of Free Software
Behringer provides a heap of free software available via download, to let you get the most out of your UAC202 right out of the box. 

 * KRISTAL Audio Engine
   KRISTAL Audio Engine is a powerful multi-track recorder, audio sequencer and mixer--ideal for anyone getting started with recording, mixing and mastering digital audio. 
 * Audacity
   Audacity is an easy-to-use audio editor and recorder for Windows, Mac OS X, and Linux operating systems. 
 * energyXT2
   This amazing DAW (digital audio workstation) makes it easy to manipulate your audio and MIDI files, and turn song ideas into stunning CD or web-ready recordings. energyXT2 includes built-in synthesizers, a drum machine, and internal multi-FX processor. 

What's in the Box
Behringer UCA202 U-Control Audio Interface, User's Manual
feature_bullets: Ultra-flexible audio interface connects your instruments, mixer, etc. with your computer for recording and playback

specifications.Special Features: With this ultra-compact, bus-powered interface, you can link your Windows and Mac computer with any audio gear. There is no setup or special drivers needed?simply plug the interface in a free USB port on your computer and get into the groove. The UCA202 provides 2 analog inputs and outputs, as well as an additional S/PDIF optical output for direct digital conversion. The stereo headphone output with dedicated level control lets you monitor both input and output. And the cherry on top is that the
specifications.Customer Reviews: 4.4 out of 5 stars2,031 ratings4.4 out of 5 stars
